question: Is RAD52 required for break-induced DNA replication (BIR) in mammalian cells? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: At CFSs, this fragility is associated with a delay in the completion of DNA replication until early mitosis, whereupon cells are proposed to switch to a RAD52-dependent form of break-induced replication.
content.source_2: In cells using alternative lengthening of telomeres, replication defects triggered mitotic DNA synthesis at telomeres in a RAD52-independent but RAD51-dependent manner, indicating that break-induced replication is not engaged by RAD52 in this context.
content.source_3: Replication stress was modeled to initiate a RAD52-dependent form of break-induced replication that completes mitotic DNA synthesis without requiring MUS81â€“EME1.
content.source_4: In mammalian cancer cells, repair of collapsed DNA replication forks occurred via break-induced replication without any measurable contribution from RAD52, as RAD51-mediated pathways fully compensated for RAD52 loss.
